text: A cavernous lobby in a high powered law firm. Marble and glass everywhere. An echo chamber. SUPERIMPOSE - Washington D.C. - October 2004

...with 21 days to the election, Time Magazine has President Bush and Senator Kerry each with 48%, a statistical dead heat... MARY MAPES sits. Career woman. Spitfire. Can drink and swear with the boys. Owns multiple curling irons. She sit alone. Waiting. KNITTING. Exhausted. Her eyes flit around as the needles loop and stitch the yarn.
Mr. Hibey will see you now.
Richly appointed. A scotch and cigar feel. Attorney DICK HIBEY (50's, bearded) rises as Mary enters.
Ms. Mapes. I'm Dick Hibey. What can I do for you?
Oh, I think you know. Hibey smiles, gestures for her to sit. Noticing:
You knit?
You don't expect a woman like me to knit.
No. But it's good. Helpful.
You mean it blunts my radical feminist agenda?
Do you have a radical feminist agenda?
You meet a lot of radical knitters? Hibey smiles politely at the joke. Then:
Do you have a substance abuse problem?
I'm working on developing one.
I'm serious.
So am I. Hibey's not smiling anymore.
You came to me, Ms. Mapes. If you're not up for this-

I've been in news for twenty years. I've won two Emmys, I broke Abu Ghraib, I've done jail time for not revealing sources. I have neither a radical feminist agenda nor a substance abuse problem, although right now I'm gonna take a xanax because this is really freaking me out - do you have any water? A beat. Hibey rises and pours Mary a glass of water from pitcher on the side table. Handing it to her.
You're going to have to be ready for questions like that.
I'm up for this.  Hibey retakes his seat. Sizing her up.
There's an interesting reoccurring theme in the stories you cover. People abusing their power.
I don't like bullies.
Tell me about your work. She looks at him.
You want to know if I'm responsible for what happened.
Aren't you?
I did my job, believe me.
I don't have to believe you. What matters is that they believe you. Now tell me about your work. Mary takes a deep breath.
I'm the producer. I find the story, I put the team together, I write and cut the piece. I work at 60 Minutes.
And what's that like? And as Mary smiles at the thought, we CUT TO --

Cramped and dark. A large screen shows a photograph of NA PRISONERS from ABU GHRAIB. An EDITOR manipulates a computer program, and one man's c is blurred out with a field of squares...  New York City - April 2004 - Six Months Earlier
They're really gonna run it this time? Mary sits behind the tech along with COLONEL ROGER CHARLE (former military 50's crewcut) and a pregnant DANA ROBERS
They're going to run it.
Because you said that last week-
They're going to run it, Roger.

You want me to paint them out like this? Mary looks up to the screen to see what the tech is doing digitally painting out men's penises image by image. One man's crotch blurred out with a field of squares.
Jesus, no, it looks like his genitals were attacked by mad cubists. Maybe you could just darken the area? The Technician hits a few keys. A beat.
Okay, now it just looks like there's a black hole there.
From which no light can escape.
They're really going to run it? Because Sy Hersh has this and he's going to write a story about how we've sat on it for three weeks-
Dana, tell Roger they're going to run it, then hit him with a large blunt object for me, will you? (MORE )
(checking her watch) I gotta go grab him, can you finish this? The Colonel nods. Mary rises as we CUT TO --
THE MAN IN PROFILE. Seated in a chair on the wings of a stage. Silhouetted by a spotlight. From ONSTAGE:

He is, among other things, a piss poor speller. That's why the Houston Chronicle put him on the radio instead of a desk. Three years later, he was their news director. Chuckles from the crowd. Our man withdraws a NOTEPAD from his pocket. Jotting something down. His speech maybe? On stage Andrew Heyward - President of CBS News (50's, mustached) addresses the crowd; a sea of tuxedos and gown

To call his beginnings humble would be generous. A graduate of that most notable of journalism schools, The Sam Houston State Teacher's College, in 1959 he took his first job in the burgeoning medium of television. A year later, when a hurricane hit Galveston, he convinced his cameraman to shoot the radar screen, showing Americans for the first time how a storm worked. He was the first journalist to report that John F. Kennedy had been shot. He described the Zapruder film in detail to a nation that was not allowed to see it. He became the White House Correspondent at 33 years of age and the Chief London Correspondent a year later. He helped bring the horrors of the Vietnam War into American living rooms for the first time. (MORE )

At a Broadcaster Convention in 1974 where President Nixon was scheduled to appear but not take questions, he, of course, asked a question. Nixon, upset, asked "Are you running for something?" My friend politely replied "No, sir, Mr. President. Are you?" Laughter. Mary slips into the back of the room.

He covered the Russians in Afghanistan and the hostages in Iran. And in 1981 he became anchor of the CBS Evening News. He has now anchored a nightly newscast for longer than anyone else in U.S. history. He has dined with kings, angered Presidents, questioned dictators. Not bad for the son of a ditch-digger from Wharton, Texas. In the wings, the Man flips his notepad shut and gets rea

Ladies and gentlemen, I give you my friend, and the reason I have this job, Dan Rather. The Crowd rises in applause as DAN RATHER steps from the wings. Mary smiles. Dan takes the lectern and pulls a pre written speech from his jacket. What was the notepad?
Thank you, Andrew, for that wonderful introduction. And yes, I will honor your speaking fee. Off the crowd's laugh we CUT TO --
After the ceremony. Dan and Andrew stand with a DRUNK RIC COUPLE during cocktail hour. Dan is in hell. Mary approaches, looking completely out of place in street clo
Hey, Andrew. I need him.
You're not taking him-
You say that, and yet here I am.
(to Mary) You've got him?
Stashed in a hotel two blocks up. They move for the door. Heyward panics, following them:
Dan, you're not leaving your own party! I got fifty affiliates and their wives waiting to meet you-- Goddammit, Mary!
Mary and Dan exit the gala. Among the fountains, Dan pull off his bow-tie like a kid after Sunday School, barely containing his glee. Pretending to be upset.
I was receiving an award, you know.
You don't say.
For a "Lifetime of Achievement".
So it's pretty much all downhill from here, then?
Brother, you ain't kidding. (pause; then) We are going to run it, right?
I'm going to start hurting you people soon, I swear to God-
I'm just saying, I've already done cut-ins for it. We kill it now, we look like fools.
Not that that's stopped us before. (crossing the street) They're worried about the Superbowl-- Andrew thinks the FCC may fine Viacom per station.
So the CBS News division has to tread softly because of Janet Jackson's left breast?

We're about to go on national television and accuse the U.S. Military of committing atrocities while hip deep in two wars during an election year. (pause) But yes, mostly I think they're worried about the boob thing.
Set up for an INTERVIEW. A TV CREW waits with a GENERAL seated in a chair. Mary and Dan enter.
General? This is Dan Rather. Dan sits opposite him, pulling the NOTEPAD from his pocke
General, thank you for doing this. Let's start from the beginning... ..-And now we see it's FULL OF QUESTIONS for the intervie

A SERIES OF QUICK SHOTS - Anonymous hands turning knobs, balancing color bars. Slotting video tapes into machines. We see a MACRO of tapeheads sliding the magnetic tape int place, spooling it through the machine...
The clock on the wall reads 8:00. We hear the familiar 60 MINUTES STOPWATCH. Colonel Charles, Dana, and others sit watching
The image of an IRAQI MAN standing on a box WEARING A HOO Electrodes run to his body. OVER THIS:

Americans did this to an Iraqi prisoner. According to the US Army, the man was told to stand on a box with his head covered with wires attached to his hands. He was told that if he fell off the box, he would be electrocuted. CUT TO Dan, addressing the camera:
It was this picture and dozens of others that prompted an investigation by the U.S. Army. Yesterday, we asked General Mark Kimmitt, deputy director of Coalition Operations in Iraq, what went wrong.
And finally to Mary, watching her story come out...
Frankly, I think all of us are disappointed at the actions of the few. You know, every day we love our soldiers, but frankly, some days we're not always proud of our soldiers.
Abu Ghraib under Saddam Hussein was infamous. For decades, many who were taken here never came out...
Ice cubes crackle. A piano plays softly. TV over the bar:  10.
...CBS's bombshell allegations this evening that prisoner abuse occurred at the Abu Ghraib facility... A few feet away, Mary, Colonel Charles, Dana and Dan sit table celebrating. Happily drunk.
I remember when you used to say "Courage" at the end of every broadcast. You remember that? (off Dan's nod) Why'd you stop?
They made fun of him.
No!
(mock wounded) They did. Me. Can you believe it?
Apparently they thought times back then weren't grave enough to warrant such a sign off.
Give us a "Courage", Dan.
I don't think-
Come on, just one. For me? A beat. Dan leans forward. In his best newscaster bariton
Courage. The others break up laughing. Dan smiles. Raises a toast.
To a hell of a story.  11.
Once they finally ran it. (vaises her glass) F.E.A. Laughter as they clink and drink, as above the TV continu to blare coverage of their story...
SUPERIMPOSE - Dallas, Texas. An inviting two story Crafts with a big front porch.
We're sitting here with Mommy. Thank you for being here Mommy.
Mary's son ROBERT (7) holds a portable video camera. Mary sits across from him as he conducts an interview with her
Thank you for having me. Robert nods, all business.
Mommy, you were away for a long time again. What were you doing?
I was in New York working on the news.
And what does that entail? Mary raises an eyebrow at her son's vocabulary.
Asking questions. Questions help reporters get to the truth.
Interesting. Are there any questions you shouldn't ask?
No. Never. Why would you say that?  12.
My friend Louis's Dad says reporters ask too many questions.
I'd be curious to know what your friend Louis's Dad thinks we should do with our time instead.
Were you with the men with the cameras?
Yes.
Interesting. Can I have a new camera?
We'll have to talk to your father about it for Christmas.
I'm trying to get to the truth here, Mommy. Answer the question. Mary smiles.
This interview is over.
Cluttered with papers. A LARGE TELEVISION above her desk. CNN yammering about Abu Ghraib.

.»..can't deny that Abu Ghraib is an enormous black eye for the Bush Administration just as John Kerry is emerging as a real challenger in the Presidential Election... Mary's husband MARK WROLSTAD appears in the doorway. Nods to the TV coverage.
Caused a bit of a ruckus, didn't you?  13.
(smiles) Who me? She clicks on her email. One from Mike Smith. I've been a bad boy. Have some tasty brisket for you. -Mike
You wanna go for a walk? Mary stares at the screen.
I think I have to work...

A SERIES OF SHOTS - Furniture being unwrapped. Boxes bein unpacked. An Oriental Rug being spread on the floor. A LINE OF EMMYS being placed one by one on a bookshelf. As the last one is put down by JOSH HOWARD, (late 30's, mustache). Looks around the office. He's made it.
Josh strides down the hall with MARY MURPHY, (30's, brune his right hand.
What's she like?
Good. Fast. She's Rather's gal. (pause) Makes twice as much as either of us.
Thanks for coming in, Mary...
Mary smiles as she enters Josh's office and shakes his ha
Not at all, I'm excited to get going.
SUPERIMPOSE - June 2004 Josh smiles back and nods to Murphy next to him.
As are we. You know Mary Murphy.
Great to see you again. Abu Ghraib was phenomenal. As they all take a seat.
So no big preamble, we love you, we love what you've done here - let's talk about the new season. What are you thinking? Mary flips open her notebook.
I got something maybe for the election. Houston businessman named Bill White claims he has documents that the Bin Laden family were investors in Arbusto.
Bush's oil company?
Could just be lots of sound and fury, but Vanity Fair's into it too. That whole time period for Bush is funky.
Funky how?
I did some work on it in 2000. You know Ben Barnes?
No.
Old Texas Pol. (MORE )

Barnes says when he was Speaker of the Texas House in '68, Sid Adger, this big oilman, comes into his office and asks for help getting young George Bush into the National Guard as a pilot. Poppy Bush at this point is a Congressman and Barnes figures he can use all the connections he can get, so he says he called General Rose, who runs the Texas Air National Guard, and gets Bush a slot.
Barnes told you this?

Completely off the record, but he's been dining out on the story for years. Then I talk to Buck Staudt, who was Bush's squadron commander. He starts screaming at me about how Barnes is full of shit, because everybody knows that he's the one who pulled the strings to get Bush into the Guard, not Barnes. Josh laughs.

Politics in Texas. It's the intergalactic capital of shit happens. Anyway while Bush is in the Guard, he meets a guy named James Bath and they become running buddies. After they get out, Bath, with no resume to speak of, becomes chief financial representative for the Bin Laden Family's interests in Texas. Bush starts up Arbusto and Bath writes him a $50,000 check.
Which your guy White claims is Bin Laden money. (off her nod) Okay, run it down. But if we go with it, we have to go early; we can't October surprise them.  16.
If you're into this, I'd like to bring in some other people.
Who? Mary reaches into her bag and hands them a list...
COLONEL CHARLES stands in full dress uniform at the funer of a VETERAN as a flag is laid over a coffin. OVER THIS:
Colonel Roger Charles, worked Abu Ghraib for us. Naval Academy grad. Two tours in Vietnam, then the Pentagon. When he's not working for us, he's trying to get better armor for combat troops in Iraq.
Who else?
LUCY SCOTT lectures a class of journalism students...
Since Dana's on maternity leave, I'd like Lucy Scott to run point. She's a CBS veteran, journalism professor in Dallas.
What about this man... Mike Smith?
A posh COCKTAIL PARTY. A long haired shaggy guy stands by huge potted plant, feeding rum-and-cokes to a clearly dru actor. Pad and pen out. This is MIKE SMITH (20's).
Mikey cut his teeth working for Molly Ivins and was a researcher for us on (MORE )
this in 2000. Last I heard, he was working as a stringer for People.com, sneaking into cocktail parties to find out who's sleeping with who...
When you say "sport-fucking", do you mean he's, like, putting it to her for fun, or that he's actively attempting to compete at it? There is a TAP on his shoulder. A BURLY SECURITY GUARD.
Sir, we have to ask you to leave.

Listen, I appreciate where you're coming from, you have your job to do, but I am protected by my First Amendment rights, so, you know, respectfully, go fuck yourself. The Security Guard rolls his eyes and looks to his goons.
The hard way.
Onlookers scatters as the goons BODILY CARRY a SCREAMING Mike Smith out the front door of the hotel:
A free press is all that stands between you roided out motherfuckers and anarchy! At-tic-a! At-tic-a! As they toss him into a FOUNTAIN...
Back to the scene. Mary gives them a smile.
It's a crack team. Trust me.  18.
A small two story building. Mary walks toward the stairca Smith sits on the stairs. Rumpled clothes and hair.
You really gonna do it this time? Your evil corporate overlords will let you?
Good to see you too, Mikey.
I hear Heyward's talking about closing foreign bureaus, moving in more of a bullshit "infotainment" direction.
Where'd you hear that?
I'm a researcher, I research.
They won't touch the news division as long as Dan's there.
Dan's not gonna be there forever. They'll figure a way to get the Old Man out of the chair eventually-
You've never even met him.
Doesn't mean his time hasn't come. Why did he get into journalism anyway if he's not gonna do tough stories? Mary looks at him.
How you doing, Mikey?
I'm eating ramen three meals a day and stealing cable, I need a job.  19.
Come meet everybody.
A series of MILITARY FILES spread out across the table. Lucy Scott and Roger Charles, working as Smith and Mary e The former Marine raises an eyebrow at the newcomer.
Oh, good. You brought me a hippie.
This is Mike Smith, he worked this with me in 2000. He has no social graces whatsoever.
It's true.
Your Arbusto tip is for shit. Bin Laden money never got near Bush.
So what am I doing here?
We found something else. Bush's time in the Guard. There are some... gaps.
You are looking at George W. Bush's entire Texas Air National Guard file.
You mean what's left of it, right? (realizing) You're doing a paper trail. The Colonel picks up a file.
What we have starts here - May 1968, bloodiest month of the conflict. Bush is accepted to the Texas Air National Guard for flight training.  20.
If you believe Ben Barnes, he got Bush onto the waiting list.
If there even was a waiting list. Some people say yes, some people say no. That one General... He snaps his fingers, trying to remember.
Belisario Flores? Colonel Charles looks at Smith - not bad.
Former head of the Texas Guard, he said there was a waiting list, over a hundred people on it.
So Bush jumped the list.
We have no document showing any kind of waiting list.

Bush says he got in so quickly because they were specifically looking for pilots, which is bullshit with so many pilots rotating back from Vietnam. And that's another thing - training a National Guard pilot from start to finish was a huge rarity.
Why?
Because it's not cost effective. Lot of National Guard jocks are former Air Force pilots who want to maintain their flight rating.
Why spend a million bucks training a new pilot when you can just admit a (MORE )
guy the Air Force already taught how to fly? The only thing that makes Bush an attractive candidate for the Guard is who he's connected to.

Either way, he's in. Signed on for a six year commitment. Does his pilot training at Moody and is then assigned to the 111th Fighter Intercept Squadron in Houston. Records show he does really well here, high marks in every rating period until the spring of 1972. Then nothing. No flights, no appearing for duty. Until August 1 when he is suspended in writing for missing a routine physical.
So how does someone go from being a top-notch pilot to not even taking your physical?
Not only that, but he requests and is granted a reassignment to Alabama to work on a friend's Senate campaign.
Wait - he disobeys an order and then they let him transfer?

It gets better. From May 1972 to May 1973, his record shows no points registered. Points are like hours on a time card in the Guard. It basically means he didn't show up. The Alabama commander has no recollection of him. No eyewitness has ever placed him on base and no paperwork exists to prove he was ever there. Lucy looks from one of them to the other.  A beat. 22.
You're telling me the President of the United States may have gone AWOL from the military for over a year?
We have no proof of that.
What does the White House say?
That Bush served honorably and that military records go missing all the time.

By the way, military records do not go missing all the time. They're the military. They're good at shit. (looking at file) Bush is not heard from in the records again until July 1973 when he shows up for drills. And in September 1973 he requests and is granted an early discharge to attend Harvard Business School.
He asks to quit nine months early and they let him?
And he resigned his commission in '74 which is very weird. You're commissioned for life, right? Why resign it? It makes no sense. Mary looks around the room.
So what are the questions we're looking to answer?
One - did Bush go into the Guard to avoid going to Vietnam?  23.
Not to be cynical, but who didn't try to get into the Guard to avoid Nam back then?
Me. The military man says it without blinking. A beat.
Bush's trainer in the 147th said he wanted to go to Vietnam.
(holds up a paper) This is the only document in the official record that deals with it. On the question of desiring overseas transfer, Bush checked "No".
Bush's trainer says that must have been a mistake.
Cause that's a question you get wrong...
Two - why did he skip the physical?
He didn't have a drug problem, he just liked the way it smelled. Lucy laughs.
And Three - if someone did pull strings for him, who? And how the hell do we get them to go on the record?
Ben Barnes (60's), former Lieutenant Governor of Texas, c in a suit. Pours a scotch on the wet bar next to his desk.  24.
...The latest Zogby poll which has Senator Kerry leading the President by seven points... Barnes on speaker-phone, voice drawls as smooth as the li
Is it that time of year again already? When I have to fend off the advances of a beautiful woman such as yourself?
You got the President into the National Guard, Governor. I find that very impressive.
It is impressive, isn't it?
Why don't you come on TV, tell us all about it?
We both know if I ever said that about Texas's favorite son on camera they'd run me outta Austin on a rail. (looking at the TV) Sorry, Mary. Johnny's gonna win this thing, anyway.
Mary ducks her head in where Mike and Lucy sit.
Barnes is still a no. Who's next? Lucy walks up to a WHITE BOARD with a LIST OF NAMES on it Draws a line through Ben Barnes. Looking to the next one.
Colonel Jerry Killian, Bush's CO in the 111th. If anyone is able to really tell us what went on, he will.  25.
Small problem there.
Which is?
Killian's dead. Lucy looks to Smith, who nods.
It's a pickle.
Who's next? Lucy lines out Jerry Killian and goes to the next...
General Buck Staudt, former CO of Bush's 147th Interceptor Squadron...
General BUCK STAUDT spitting mad as he yells into the pho
George was one of the best fucking pilots I ever had! I resent all you goddamn reporters implying that something fishy was going on!
Lucy lines out Buck Staudt and moves onto the next.
General Bobby Hodges, succeeded Staudt as Commander of the 147th, Killian's direct supervisor...
Mary, phone to her ear, hearing:
He was like all Second Lieutenants, bright eyed and bushy tailed. But no strings were pulled for him.  INT. 26.
Bobby Hodges lined out. Onto the next: INT. INT. INT. INT. EXT. INT. INT.
Maurice Udell, Bush's flight instructor...
(into phone) No strings were pulled for him. I thought he'd be a great American and a fighter pilot.
Tom Honeycutt...
(into phone) No strings were pulled.
Albert Lloyd...
(into phone) No strings were pulled.
Bill Hollowell.
(into phone) No strings were pulled. And even if they were, it's a non-issue. (MORE )
(honks at another car) Move, you son of a bitch!
SUPERIMPOSE - August 2004. Every last name on the board h a line through it. Mary sits, staring at the names. Tryin to find a way in.
Dan, getting dressed for a black tie event. Mary talks to him through his speaker-phone, INTERCUT:
It's like they were given talking points. He was a great guy and no strings were pulled.
Devil's advocate? What if no strings were pulled?
You know who else was in the 147th? Lloyd Bensten's son, John Connally's son, both Sid Adger's sons, H.L. Hunt's grandson, and the heirs to the Sakowitz fortune. But I'm sure it's just a coincidence.
So what's our next move? Mary shakes her head. Staring at the names.
I have no idea.
Late. Wrolstad snores lightly. On Mary. Can't sleep. The TV plays. A SWIFT BOAT AD. A montage of older VETERANS speaking to the camera, with a background of military ima
I served with John Kerry.
I served with John Kerry.
John Kerry has not been honest about what happened in Vietnam.
He is lying about his record.
John Kerry has not been honest...
And he lacks the capacity to lead.
When the chips were down, you could not count on John Kerry.
John Kerry is no war hero- The PHONE RINGS. Wrolstad stirs in the bed next to her.
Who's that?
My secret lover. Go back to sleep. Wrolstad grunts and rolls over. Mary scoops up the receiv
Hello?
You ever hear of Linda Starr? Runs a website, clearing house for anti- Bush stuff. She's hinting documents are going to be floated soon.
What kind of documents?
Josh drinks coffee as an ASSISTANT pokes her head in.  29.
Mary Mapes is on the phone.
Mary, bleary, handwritten notes in front of her, fixing a bowl of Cheerios for Robert across from her. INTERCUT:

I think we got something. Anti-Bush internet rabble-rouser. I talked to her for three hours, but she put me in touch with her source, a Colonel who says he may have access to missing documents from Bush's purged Guard file. I got Mike Smith talking to him right now. Robert looks at his bowl. Mary INT. Mary cups
Milk? retrieves a carton of milk from the fridge.
Get a look at those documents. And do some background, make sure the Colonel isn't nuts.
sits in a booth across from reporter JIM MOORE. Steaming of coffee in front of both of them.
Colonel Burkett is nuts.
Oh, good.
But he's also on the level.
You're sure?
He's a whistle-blower. (MORE )

And whistle-blowers are consistently unbalanced, angry grudge-holders. That's what makes them want to blow their whistles in the first place. (leaning forward) He claims he was there for the scrubbing.
The scrubbing?

Of Bush's Guard file. 1997, Burkett, George Conn, a couple other people say that a bunch of Bushies went down to the Guard Headquarters in Austin and made certain unfavorable parts of his file disappear. You've seen the official record right? Holes in it big enough to drive a truck through.
So you believe him.
Enough to devote a hundred and twenty pages in my new book to him. He takes a sip of his coffee.
You're going to want to be careful with this. The administration doesn't take kindly to this type of reporting.
I didn't exactly make friends with them on Abu Ghraib-
This is different. You're talking about screwing with the man himself.
The President.  31.
After I did my first book on Bush? My name mysteriously popped up on the terrorist no-fly list. Now, I can't hop a puddle jumper without a strip search. They don't forget.
Mary coming home, hears SMITH'S VOICE coming from the kit
...Then you gotta know about the 1996 Telcom Act...
Smith sits across from Robert, who is interviewing him.

See, the rules were no company could own more than one TV station, radio station, or newspaper in the same market - so no one could have a monopoly on the flow of information. But the '96 Act eliminated the cross ownership ban and now TV News is controlled by only five corporations - GE, Disney, Time Warner, NewsCorp, and Viacom - which owns CBS. And all of these mega-corporations rely on what? Robert just stares at him.
I'm seven.

On corporate tax breaks and favorable government legislation! That means the government controls the financial well-being of the very institutions that are supposed to report on them! At best it's collusion. Can you still report the news? Sure. As long as it doesn't get in the way of the golden rule - thou shalt always protect the company.  32.
Ever think maybe you're just paranoid? Smith turns to see her standing there. Silence.
Once. But I dismissed it as paranoia. (vising) We have a problem. Burkett's talking to other outlets. New York Times, Vanity Fair-
You gotta get him to meet with us and bring the documents.
He does that, he loses all his bargaining power. He wants money.
We don't do that.
He's worried he's going to have to relocate after this. He's worried this will put him in danger. Shit, he's worried his phone is tapped.
Aren't you?
Mary, if these really are missing pieces of a sitting President's military record, we are talking about the Holy Grail of documents. If we won't pay, someone else will. The clock ticks. Mary, slowly:
Tell Burkett we don't believe him.
But we do believe him.  33.
Tell him if he wants to keep us on the hook, he's going to have to show us something to prove his story. Smith stares at her.
You get me in a room with those documents, and I will close him.
Deep Texas. A burger chain. The sign blares WHATABURGER! SUPERIMPOSE - September 2004. Mary and Smith pull to a ha in front of the bright orange restaurant. After a bit:
You figure they really have to have confidence in their burgers to name a restaurant that. Smith nods. Then:
How early are we? A beat. They exchange a glance, thinking the same thing..
Mary and Smith, now EATING BURGERS. Smith, mouth full:
These are really good. Mary nods. Scanning the people outside.
What do they look like?
The Burketts? I don't know.
Then how do we recognize them?  34.
I don't know, I thought you Googled them or something.

We've arranged a clandestine Whataburger rendezvous with a man who wants to bring down the President of the United States and we don't even know what he looks like? A RAPPING on Mary's window and she turns to see a very TA OLDER WOMAN standing there. Behind her is a taller gaunt older man. COLONEL BILL BURKETT. Looks around, suspicious
Y'all stay in the car. In case someone listened to our calls, we're gonna go to a secondary location. Mary gives Smith a look as Burkett heads back to his car.

The foursome occupy a BOOTH. Colorful kids' placemats in front of them. A birthday party in the background. Nicki helps Burkett take sucks off an oxygen mask, as a WAITRES delivers four huge sodas to the table. When she's gone--
I saw it with my own eyes. They put the parts of Bush's file they didn't like in a wastebasket.
And do you have these documents?
Bill tried to talk about this in 2000 and someone ran us off the road one night.
I ain't scared of them-
Well, I am. I am scared. She takes a deep gulp of iced tea. Nerves shot.
Let's say I have the documents. Why should we show 'em to you? Why not one of the newspapers-
